entry.title: Project Euler problem 51
entry.summary:
Prime digit replacements
By replacing the 1st digit of the 2-digit number *3, it turns out that six of the nine possible values: 13, 23, 43, 53, 73, and 83, are all prime.
By replacing the 3rd and 4th digits of 56**3 with the same digit, this 5-digit

entry.title: Integer partition with python and erlang
entry.summary: In number theory and combinatorics, a partition of a positive integer n, also called an integer partition, is a way of writing n as a sum of positive integers. Two sums that differ only in the order of their summands are considered the same partition.

entry.title: Project Euler problem 49
entry.summary:
Prime permutations
The arithmetic sequence, 1487, 4817, 8147, in which each of the terms increases by 3330, is unusual in two ways: (i) each of the three terms are prime, and, (ii) each of the 4-digit numbers are permutations of one another.
There are no arithmetic sequences made up of three 1-, 2-, or 3-digit primes, exhibiting this property, but there is one other 4-digit increasing sequence.

entry.title: Project Euler problem 48
entry.summary:
Self powers
The series, 1^1 + 2^2 + 3^3 + … + 10^10 = 10405071317.
Find the last ten digits of the series, 1^1 + 2^2 + 3^3 + … + 1000^1000.

entry.title: Project Euler problem 47
entry.summary:
Distinct primes factors
The first two consecutive numbers to have two distinct prime factors are:
14 = 2 × 7 15 = 3 × 5
The first three consecutive numbers to have three distinct prime factors are:
644 = 2² × 7 × 23 645 = 3 × 5 × 43 646 = 2 × 17 × 19.

entry.title: Project Euler problem 46
entry.summary:
Goldbach’s other conjecture
It was proposed by Christian Goldbach that every odd composite number can be written as the sum of a prime and twice a square.
9 = 7 + 2×1^2 15 = 7 + 2×2^2 21 = 3 + 2×3^2 25 = 7 + 2×3^2 27 = 19 + 2×2^2 33 = 31 + 2×1^2
